description: From the Latin diremptus (“separated, divided”), the past participle of dirimō (“I separate, divide”), formed as dir- (prevocalic variant of dis- (“apart, asunder”)) + emō (“I take”); compare dirempt².

entries.meaning: (obsolete, past participial) Distinct; separate; secrete; divided.
examples: Tacitus, that Bobotria & Blota haue ſundry paſſages into the sea and are clerely dirempt one from the other

description: From the Latin *diremptō, frequentative of dirimō.

verbs.description: dirempt (third-person singular simple present dirempts, present participle dirempting, simple past and past participle dirempted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, principally in philosophy) To separate; to divide; to break off.
